awd_titl_txt: Analysis and geometry on non-smooth spaces
awd_abstract_narration:
In many natural phenomena geometric patterns arise that cannot be described by classical mathematical tools. Often these patterns have a self-similar or fractal nature. Examples include snowflakes and crystals, urban and plant growth, mountain ranges and coastlines, lightning bolts, or river networks.  This project intends to contribute to the development of analytic methods  that are useful  for the investigation of such geometric features  and their deeper understanding. The PI will involve his PhD students and other young researchers in this activity. This  will contribute to increasing  the  expertise in this area  and will help to maintain a scientific community that provides the necessary mathematical knowledge  for  progress in science and engineering. 

In mathematics fractal or non-smooth spaces often arise from  dynamical systems as  limit sets of Kleinian groups or as Julia sets of rational maps. In this project the analysis and geometry of such  spaces will be explored  and new mathematical tools for their investigation be created. Specifically, the PI  intends  to study the relation between certain Sobolev-type functions  on  fairly general metric spaces and corresponding functions  on their hyperbolic fillings. In the second part of the project  this  will be applied to a relevant model case where such non-smooth spaces appear, namely the dynamics of Thurston maps.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Mathematical and Physical Sciences

por.por_cntn:
In this project various aspects of the analysis and geometry of non-smooth or fractal spaces were studied. This was motivated by the fact that fractals often arise in mathematics and that many natural phenomena exhibit fractal features. The main objective was to lay the mathematical foundations for a better understanding of typical fractals and explore some of the underlying questions in specific cases.  The fractals investigated were often related to some type of dynamical system such as Julia sets of a rational maps or attractors of a iterated function systems. 
 
Intellectual merit:  New analytic methods for the investigation of fairly general metric spaces were developed, in particular for spaces that have few rectifiable curves and for which some of the standard analytic tools (such as Poincaré inequalities) fail. This relied on Sobolev-type functions, hyperbolic fillings, and the notion of weak capacity.  Some of these methods were applied for an in-depth study of the quasiconformal geometry of Sierpinski carpets and of metric 2-spheres that arise as visual spheres of expanding Thurston maps. 

Broader impact: The project resulted in more than twenty publications by the PI and his students. The PI  completed a research monograph on ``Expanding Thurston Maps" (joint with D. Meyer) that was published in the fall of 2017. The PI trained five PhD students as part of the project. 


Last Modified: 09/10/2018
Modified by: Mario Bonk
